sen.j: 『野ざらし紀行』（のざらしきこう）は、江戸時代中期の俳諧師松尾芭蕉の紀行。
sen.e: "Nozarashi Kiko" (Journal of Bleached Bones in a Field) is the travel records by Basho MATSUO, haikai (seventeen-syllable verse) poet in the mid-Edo Period.

sen.j: 貞享元年（1684年）秋の8月から翌年4月にかけて、芭蕉が門人の千里とともに出身地でもある伊賀上野への旅を記した俳諧紀行文。
sen.e: It consists of haikai poetry dealing with a journey his disciple Chiri set out for Iga Ueno, the Basho's birthplace, from August (autumn) 1684 to April of the following year.

sen.j: 「野ざらし」は、旅立ちに際して詠んだ一句｢野ざらしを心に風のしむ身かな｣に由来する。
sen.e: The word "Nozarashi" came from Basho's poetry "Nozarashi o kokoro ni kaze no shimu mi kana" (bleached bones on my mind, the wind pierces my body to the heart) that he wrote at the departure of the journey.

sen.j: 芭蕉は前年に死去した母の墓参を目的に、江戸から東海道を伊勢へ赴き、伊賀上野を経て大和国から美濃国大垣、名古屋などを巡る。
sen.e: Basho's aim of the journey was to visit the grave of his mother who died the previous year; he and Chiri left Edo and traveled Tokaido to Ise, from where they set out for Iga Ueno to Yamato Province, Ogaki in Mino Province, and Nagoya; on the New Year they were in Iga and then traveled through Kyoto and Osaka area, stayed in Atsuta for a while, went across Kai Province and finally headed back to Edo.

sen.j: 芭蕉は江戸を経つと箱根で霧しぐれに隠れる富士を趣深いと感じ、駿河では富士川のほとりで捨て子を見て、「猿を聞く人捨て子に秋の風いかに」と詠んで杜甫の心境に迫ろうとした。
sen.e: Basho left Edo and set out for Hakone where he found enchanting that the Mount Fuji that was hidden by misty rain; in Suruga, he was walking along the Fuji River when he saw an abandoned child and wrote a poem "Saru o kiku hito sutego ni aki no kaze ika ni" (those who listen for the monkeys: what of this child in the autumn wind?) to get into Du Fu's mindset.
